Award.AbstractNarration:
The Ecological Patterning and Effects of Child Care Markets

PI: Josh Pacewicz
Co-PI: Jennifer Bouek

As mothers have flooded into the workforce over the past fifty years, children have entered into institutionalized and non maternal care environments in equally dramatic trends. These seismic social shifts have generated widespread debate around the implications of institutionalized care for child wellbeing. Yet, we know little about the ecological and organizational environments in which families arrange for their children's care. This project questions how and why local child care markets vary across communities and how this variation impacts families' child care choices and maternal employment opportunities. Beyond theoretical contributions, this project will sharpen the currently limited understanding of child care as an organizational field, responding to questions of equitable access, variations in quality and safety, and structural barriers to finding care. Results will be of interest to policymakers and social advocacy groups seeking to improve access to and the quality of child care, especially at a time of rising political interest in child care.

This dissertation employs mixed-methods to examine the ecological patterning and effects of child care markets. The project is based upon a comparative and multiscalar research design, drawing data from four neighborhoods within two cities in two states. Phase one links state administrative records of child care providers and media archives with American Community Survey data within two of the largest American cities (Boston, MA and Houston, TX) which embody contrasting regulatory and social policy environments. Using spatial analysis and logistic regression, the project analyzes how the quality, safety and composition of local child care markets varies as a function of neighborhood disadvantage. Results from phase one provide the foundation for phase two, in which two neighborhoods within each city, each with similar socio demographic profiles but contrasting child care markets, are chosen for ethnographic study. Within each neighborhood, semi-structured in-depth interviews will be conducted among three groups of stakeholders: (1) mothers, (2) care providers, and (3) bureaucrats and nonprofit workers. Interviews will provide data on how markets are formed, why they vary, and the implications for families. The geocoded dataset from phase one, archive materials and non-confidential interview transcripts from phase two will be made available to the public. Summary reports will also be provided to nonprofit groups working within the communities of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jennifer Bouek has finalized data collection for her dissertation, "The Ecological Patterning and Effects of Child Care Markets," with the support of the National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. This award helped to support nearly three years of fieldwork during which Bouek investigated how a mother’s institutional and organizational child care setting shapes her access to care, and the effects on her economic future. Bouek conducted a total of 94 formal interviews among mothers of young children, child care providers, and state and non-state policymakers in both Boston and Houston, in addition to 35 hours of observation at state public meetings, archival analysis of public administrative records, and dozens of informal interviews. As a sociologist of inequality and the social welfare state, Bouek was especially interested in how state practice, policy, and politics shaped mothers’ divergent pathways into child care, and how child care continues to operate as a vehicle of gendered economic inequality.  

 

This research has yielded three important insights about mothers’ equitable access to child care. First, analysis of public records revealed that child care centers in historically disadvantaged communities have higher rates of incident reporting and inspection violations than those located in better-resourced communities and are closing at higher rates, such that many poor communities of color are facing an impending collapse of their child care. These findings can largely be attributed to the resource constraint created by state agencies’ low reimbursement rates and, more broadly, the privatization of child care. Second, the prioritization of populations for subsidized care, for example families in state protective custody or homeless families, is creating a system of tiered access that has ramifications at the organizational and individual level: centers are increasingly overwhelmed by the influx of families entering into care through the state, leading many to close, and many otherwise eligible families are being sidelined for care through both formal and informal state mechanisms. Third, the structure of the child care market is especially significant for middle income mothers who do not qualify for state assistance but who cannot afford private tuition. For these mothers, the absence of child care contributes to their economic descent.

 

This research has been communicated to both academic and public audiences. Bouek has presented findings at three professional conferences and has submitted two articles for review in scholarly journals. In addition, Bouek has shared results from dissertation fieldwork with multiple community and advocacy organizations and is currently drafting an opinion piece for publication in a public outlet. These results form the basis of her dissertation, which will be defended in the fall of 2019.
